title: Kasatkina's Journey to Australian Citizenship and Tennis Relief
summary: Daria Kasatkina, a Russian-born tennis player ranked world number 48, has gained Australian citizenship and is competing in the 2025 Australian Open as a home player. She expresses relief, stating she can finally breathe and live without the stress of external issues beyond her control. Kasatkina has faced significant challenges, including playing as a neutral athlete since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022 and coming out as gay, which led her to leave Russia. She described the war as a nightmare and ended her 2024 season early due to mental and emotional strain. Now, as the new Australian number two, she is preparing to play against Czech teenager Nikola Bartunkova and anticipates strong support from the Melbourne crowd. Kasatkina views this as a positive pressure compared to her past struggles, marking a special chapter in her life. The article also notes that her friend Mirra Andreeva is currently Russia's top women's player.

background_read: Daria Kasatkina is a professional tennis player from Russia who has been competing internationally. In 2022, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, international sports bodies required Russian athletes to compete as neutrals, without national representation. Around the same time, Kasatkina publicly came out as gay, a significant step in a country with restrictive LGBTQ+ laws, leading her to leave Russia. These events caused her emotional distress, impacting her performance and leading to an early end to her 2024 season. Recently, she obtained Australian citizenship, allowing her to represent Australia and play as a home player in tournaments like the Australian Open. This change is part of a broader trend of athletes seeking new nationalities due to political or personal reasons, highlighting issues of identity and safety in sports.
